revision.comment: /* SEC Suit Against Mudd, Syron, et al. */
revision.text:
== SEC Suit Against Mudd, Syron, et al. ==
The SEC sued former executives of Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac based on their disclosures about the GSEs’ exposure to subprime loans. The two companies were not sued, and have agreed to cooperate with the SEC.
The Fannie Mae [http://sec.gov/litigation/complaints/2011/comp-pr2011-267-fanniemae.pdf suit] is against Daniel Mudd, former CEO; Enrico Dallavecchia, former Chief Risk Officer; and Thomas Lund, former Single-Family Credit Guarantee EVP. The SEC alleges that from December 6, 2006 through August 8, 2008, Fannie Mae repeatedly underdisclosed its subprime exposure. The SEC alleges that Fannie Mae used a disclosed definition of subprime, but that in calculating its exposure, it excluded expanded approval (EA) loans and MyCommunityMortgage (MCM) loans, which the SEC says “fell squarely within Fannie Mae’s publicly stated definition of subprime[.]” After Fannie Mae was in conservatorship, the SEC says that Fannie Mae for the first time publicly acknowledged that it held loans that matched its definition of Alt-A that it had not reported in its Alt-A exposure. The SEC also alleges that Fannie Mae disclosed that it classified loans as Alt-A if the lender delivering the loans did so, but that Fannie Mae did not disclose that it directed lenders whether to label reduced-documentation loans as Alt-A. The complaint also includes statements that it says Mudd made to Congress in April 2007, including that “less than 2.5 percent of our book can be defined as subprime.” The SEC alleges its subprime exposure was actually considerably higher.
The Freddie Mac [http://sec.gov/litigation/complaints/2011/comp-pr2011-267-freddiemac.pdf suit] is against Richard Syron, former CEO, Patricia Cook, former EVP of Investments and Capital Markets, and Chief Business Officer, and Donald Bisenius, former SVP of Credit Policy and Portfolio Management. The SEC alleges that from March 23, 2007 through August 6, 2008, Freddie Mac similarly underreported its subprime exposure. It alleges that the defendants were aware the Freddie Mac was increasing its exposure to lower quality loans, but its public disclosures were inconsistent with how management characterized its use of the term “subprime” for its board members. The SEC alleges that Syron and Cook were given reports that the 2007 book performance was worse than in 2006, and that October 2007 expected default costs “are 76% higher than in 2006[.]” The SEC alleges that Syron and Cook said in 2007 that Freddie Mac had “basically no subprime exposure in our guarantee business, and about $124 billion of AAA rated subprime exposure in our retained portfolio.” The complaint alleges that in December 2007, Syron said, “we didn’t buy any subprime loans. I mean, we bought some securities, which we can go through, and we think we’re fine in. We bought them for goal purposes. But we didn’t buy in guarantee, essentially any subprime loans. So we weren’t in that business.” The SEC alleges that at the time, Freddie Mac had $206 billion of exposure to loans that it internally recognized as “subprime,” “otherwise subprime,” or “subprime-like.”
=== SEC Web page === Has pie charts showing subprime discrepancies, etc. *[http://www.sec.gov/news/press/2011/2011-267.htm Page] **[http://www.sec.gov/litigation/complaints/2011/comp-pr2011-267-freddiemac.pdf Freddie Executives] **[http://www.sec.gov/litigation/complaints/2011/comp-pr2011-267-fanniemae.pdf Fannie Executives] **[http://www.sec.gov/news/press/2011/npa-pr2011-267-freddiemac.pdf Freddie NPA] **[http://www.sec.gov/news/press/2011/npa-pr2011-267-fanniemae.pdf Fannie NPA]

*[http://www.sifma.org/research/reports.aspx Reports] *[http://www.sifma.org/research/ Research] *[http://www.sifma.org/research/statistics.aspx Statistics] mostly xls *[http://www.sifma.org/research/item.aspx?id=23030 CPR and PSA
==Related== *[http://www.securitization.net/publications/pdfs/StoneZissu_Cpt3.pdf Valuation of Mortgage- and Asset-Backed Securities] WAL, CPR, PSA, etc. Also some summary tables that can be used to check calculations m(t) = m(0)(1-cpr)^t *[http://www.fanniemae.com/mbs/mbsbasics/market/yield.jhtml?p=Mortgage-Backed+Securities&s=Basics+of+Fannie+Mae+MBS&t=Basics+of+MBS+Market+&+Pools&q=Understanding+Yield Basics of Fannie Mae MBS] Several models have been developed to calculate cash flow. Each uses expectations of mortgage repayments together with price to determine yield. Fannie Mae does not recommend any particular model and no guaranty can be made that the use of a particular model will be beneficial to an investor. The major difference among these methods is the assumption or methodology used to forecast how quickly principal will be returned. Market analysts and research departments at major investment firms continually monitor mortgage prepayment activity. Extensive prepayment histories are publicly available through these firms. Constant Prepayment Rate (CPR) and Bond Market Association Standard Prepayment Model (PSA curve) are the most popular models used to measure prepayments. CPR represents the annualized constant rate of principal repayment in excess of scheduled principal amortization. The PSA curve is a schedule of prepayments that assumes that prepayments will occur at a rate of 0.2 percent CPR in the first month and will increase an additional 0.2 percent CPR each month until the 30th month and will prepay at a rate of 6 percent CPR thereafter ("100 percent PSA"). PSA prepayment speeds are expressed as a multiple of this base scenario. For example, 200 percent PSA assumes annual prepayment rates will be twice as fast in each of these periods -- 0.4 percent in the first month, 0.8 percent in the second month, reaching 12 percent in month 30 and remaining at 12 percent after that. A zero percent PSA assumes no prepayments.

== Public Laws == *[http://localhost/docs/PL/pl_73-43_(Home_Owners_Loan_Act_of_1933).pdf PL 73-43, Home Owners Loan Act of 1933] *[http://localhost/docs/PL/pl_73-479_(National_Housing_Act).pdf PL 73-479, National Housing Act] *[http://localhost/docs/PL/pl_81-176_(To_provide_an_increase_in_the_authorization_for_the_federal_national_mortgage_association).pdf PL 81-176, To Provide an Increase in the Authorization for the Federal National Mortgage Association] *[http://localhost/docs/PL/pl_82-531_(Housing_Act_of_1952).pdf PL 82-531, Housing Act of 1952] *[http://localhost/docs/PL/pl_82-558_(To_Amend_Title_IV_of_the_National_Housing_Act).pdf PL 82-558, To amend title IV of the National Housing Act, as amended] *[http://localhost/docs/PL/pl_84-345_(Housing_Amendments_of_1955).pdf PL 84-345, Housing Amendments of 1955] *[http://localhost/docs/PL/pl_85-10_(To_provide_interim_assistance_through_the_Federal_National_Mortgage_Association).pdf PL 85-10, To Provide Interim Assistance Through the Federal National Mortgage Association] *[http://localhost/docs/PL/pl_89-556_(To_stimulate_the_flow_of_mortgage_credit).pdf PL 89-556, To Simulate the Flow of Mortgage Credit] *[http://localhost/docs/PL/pl_88-560_(Housing_Act_of_1964).pdf PL 88-560, Housing Act of 1964] *[http://localhost/docs/PL/pl_101-73_(FIRREA_of_1989).pdf PL 101-73, Financial Institutions Reform, Recovery, and Enforcement Act of 1989 (FIRREA)] *[http://localhost/docs/PL/pl_101-625_(Cranston_Gonzales_National_Affordable_Housing_Act).pdf PL 101-625, Cranston-Gonzalez National Affordable Housing Act] *[http://localhost/docs/PL/pl_102-550_(Housing_and_Community_Development_Act_of_1992).pdf PL 102-550, Federal Housing Enterprises Financial Safety and Soundness Act of 1992]
== Charters == *[http://localhost/docs/PL/pl_90-448_(Housing_and_Urban_Development_Act_of_1968).pdf PL 90-448, Housing and Urban Development Act of 1968 (Federal National Mortgage Association Charter Act) ] Fannie Mae
*[http://localhost/docs/PL/pl_91-351_(Emergency_Home_Finance_Act_of_1970).pdf PL 91-351, Emergency Home Finance Act of 1980 (Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation Charter Act) ] Freddie Mac *[http://localhost/docs/PL/pl_101-73_(FIRREA_of_1989).pdf PL 101-73FIRREA] Freddie Mac Privatization

*[http://www.newyorkfed.org/mortgagemaps/ Dynamic Maps of Nonprime Mortgage Conditions in the United States (NY Fed)]
==Subprime (Historic)== *[http://www.huduser.org/portal/publications/fairhsg/unequal.html HUD (2000)] **[http://archives.hud.gov/reports/subprime/subprime.cfm Full Report] **[http://www.huduser.org/portal/datasets/manu.html Subprime and Mfg Housing Lender List] *[http://www.federalreserve.gov/pubs/feds/2008/200829/200829pap.pdf Subprime Mortgages: What, Where, and to Whom?] Federal Reserve Board (2008), Chris Mayer and Karen Pence *[http://www.huduser.org/Publications/pdf/wkgpapr_7.pdf HMDA Coverage of the Mortgage Market] HUD(1998) Randall Scheessele -- An important issue in these analyses concerns the accuracy and coverage of HMDA data. HMDA coverage of the primary and secondary market has been debated for several years. Berkovec and Zorn (1996) conclude that 1992 and 1993 HMDA data cover 66 percent and 70 percent of Freddie Mac purchases. Inside Mortgage Finance (September 6, 1996), however, reports that 1995 HMDA numbers are within one percent of originations reported by HUD’s Survey of Mortgage Lending. Recently, Fannie Mae stated that “HMDA data is seriously flawed” and “notoriously unreliable in tracking secondary market activity”. We disagree with Fannie Mae’s harsh criticism of HMDA data. Bunce and Scheessele (1996), The GSEs’ Funding of Affordable Loans, provide a good discussion of the limitations of HMDA data and include a discussion of HMDA’s under-reporting of GSE purchases. Bunce and Scheessele conclude that HMDA is the most comprehensive data base available for estimating the market shares for primary and secondary mortgage market activity.
*[http://www.philadelphiafed.org/community-development/publications/discussion-papers/subprime-lending-over-time-the-role-of-race.pdf Subprime Lending over Time: The Role of Race] Philadelphia Fed (2010) Marving Smith and Christy Chung Hevener Despite the recent growth in the subprime mortgage market, little is known about subprime borrowers, their default experience, or subprime lenders’ underwriting practices. This report will help to expand what is known by looking at lending practices in the subprime mortgage market and the current and potential role of Fannie Mac and Freddie Mac. The report is based on a review of relevant literature and a series of interviews with subprime and prime lenders and representatives of consumer groups, regulators, investment banks and trade associations.
*[http://www.huduser.org/Publications/pdf/subprime.pdf Subprime Markets, The Role of GSEs, and Risk-Based Pricing] Efforts to promote equal access to mortgage capital by racial and ethnic minorities have historically been a key component of the civil rights agenda in the United States. From the struggle to enact fair housing and fair lending legislation in the 1960s to the community-based advocacy that prompted Congress to pass the Home Mortgage Disclosure Act (HMDA) and the Community Reinvestment Act in the 1970s, housing and civil rights advocates have pursued a common goal of eradicating racial discrimination in home mortgage lending. Today, the fight continues as housing advocates seek to expand regulatory and legislative action to halt predatory lending practices that burden many minorities with mortgages they cannot afford and often do not need.
*[http://www.jchs.harvard.edu/sites/jchs.harvard.edu/files/w05-11.pdf The Dual Mortgage Market: The Persistence of Discrimination in Mortgage Lending]Efforts to promote equal access to mortgage capital by racial and ethnic minorities have historically been a key component of the civil rights agenda in the United States. From the struggle to enact fair housing and fair lending legislation in the 1960s to the community-based advocacy that prompted Congress to pass the Home Mortgage Disclosure Act (HMDA) and the Community Reinvestment Act in the 1970s, housing and civil rights advocates have pursued a common goal of eradicating racial discrimination in home mortgage lending. Today, the fight continues as housing advocates seek to expand regulatory and legislative action to halt predatory lending practices that burden many minorities with mortgages they cannot afford and often donot need.
*[https://research.stlouisfed.org/publications/review/06/01/ChomPennCross.pdf The Evolution of the Subprime Mortgage Market] This paper describes subprime lending in the mortgage market and how it has evolved through time. Subprime lending has introduced a substantial amount of risk-based pricing into the mortgage market by creating a myriad of prices and product choices largely determined by borrower credit history (mortgage and rental payments, foreclosures and bankruptcies, and overall credit scores) and down payment requirements. Although subprime lending still differs from prime lending in many ways, much of the growth (at least in the securitized portion of the market) has come in the least-risky (A–) segment of the market. In addition, lenders have imposed prepayment penalties to extend the duration of loans and required larger down payments to lower their credit risk exposure from high-risk loans.
*[http://www.woodstockinst.org/publications/download/two-steps-back%3a-the-dual-mortgage-market,-predatory-lending-and-the-undoing-of-community-development/ Two Steps Back] In the last few years, predatory mortgage lending has become an increasingly critical issue facing those working to promote community reinvestment. Predatory lending practices include, but are not limited to, fraudulent, high-pressure, or misleading marketing and sales; the “packing” and financing of unnecessary fees; and “flipping” or overly frequent refinancing with fees being repeatedly rolled into the loan. These and similar practices are threatening years of community development progress across the country. The restructuring of financial services industries and the failure of federal and state regulators to respond to these changes have increased the ability of certain lenders and brokers to exploit homeowners, particularly in minority and modest-income communities. This report describes predatory lending, identifies some explanations for its growth in recent years, quantifies the hypersegmentation of lending by neighborhood racial composition, and calls for a set of policy changes to curb abuses.

== Sean == Understanding the Subprime Mortgage Crisis http://research.stlouisfed.org/wp/2008/2008-036.pdf
Our principal data source is the ABS Database from Corelogic-LoanPerformance (hereafter, LP) data repository containing loan-level data on securitized mortgages.4 We restrict our analysis to loan-level data on over nine million .rst-lien securitized subprime mortgages, originated between 2000 and 2006.5 Signi.cantly, our study comprises of originations that were securitized and within the securitized subprime universe, the coverage on these loans are fairly high especially for the later cohorts. Summary data on subprime originations over the years record a signi.cant increase in the proportion of adjustable rate mortgages (mainly hybrid-ARMs). In addition, these years saw a sharp increase in the proportion of low-documentation loans and a signi.cant deterioration in loan-to-value ratios (see GAO, 2010 for details). Interestingly however, and contrary to perceived wisdom, this deteriora- tion of loan quality was hardly a secular trend. As mentioned earlier, we draw attention to two patterns that went against this trend. First, we demonstrate that there was a signi.- cant increase in the credit quality on subprime originations as measured by their origination FICO scores. We also note that this change is a subprime phenomenon and not a result of changes in creditworthiness of the U.S. population. Second, we examine the minimum criterion for obtaining a subprime loan in terms of origination characteristics over the two periods. We find that in terms of some basic observable origination characteristics, the minimum criterion to obtain a subprime loan actually strengthened over the two periods.
From: Getter, Darryl Sent: Wednesday, May 30, 2012 9:47 AM To: Murphy, Ted; Nagel, Jared; Weiss, Eric; Hoskins, Sean Subject: I might have found it!!!
Gents,
Check out page 30 of this TCW group report at https://www.tcw.com/News_and_Commentary/News/Webcast_Schedule_Replays/~/media/Downloads/News/ConferenceCalls/080910TSI.ashx. It appears that the FICO scores and LTVs remained fairly stable until after 2008 when FHA's business started to ramp up. At any rate, before Susan Watcher tries to show that credit standards were loosened, it would help if she might make an attempt to reconcile some of the info that we have on credit scores & DTI ratios. Supposedly, if we were living in a world of risk-based pricing and automated underwriting (credit scores), then it theoretically should have been OK to require lower down payments. So she may be correct, but it would help to tell a better, more complete story.
Thanks for everyone's help!!! DG

I apologize again for the delay this morning. Here is the study done by UNC and CRL that I referenced: http://www.ccc.unc.edu/abstracts/QRMunderwriting.php
Carolina Reid works for CRL and was one of the authors. Carolina K. Reid Senior Researcher Center for Responsible Lending 1330 Broadway, Suite #604 Oakland, CA 94612 Phone: 510-379-5524
This piece from the FHFA might be of some help in documenting the rise of low FICO, high LTV as a share of the GSE and PLS market. The data is in the index at the back.
http://www.fhfa.gov/webfiles/16711/RiskChars9132010.pdf
Also, the GAO did a study on the impact of QRM and QM and estimated market share of loans that would have been excluded by QM. Because of limitations in the data, they could only quantify a few of the restrictions (pages 22-24). Perhaps the UNC data set might be more robust.
http://www.gao.gov/new.items/d11656.pdf
I hope that this helps.
